title: How to Remove Cooking Oil, Grease, and Butter Stains from Clothes

steps.title: Scrape off the excess oil and blot the area with a paper towel.
steps.content: Scrape off the excess oil and blot the area with a paper towel. Use a butter knife, spoon, or old credit card to scrape off any solids or pooling grease. Blot the spot with a clean white paper towel or cloth to absorb as much oil as possible. [1] X Research source If the oil has already dried up, move on to the next step. Plain paper towels are best for this step—colored cloths or paper towels with printed patterns may transfer color onto your clothing. Optionally, pretreat the area with a prewash stain remover . [2] X Research source Looking for other ways to remove grease stains from your clothes? Check out wikiHow’s “How do I get grease stains out of my clothes?” forum .

steps.title: Apply baking soda and let it soak up the oil for 5 to 10 minutes, then brush it off.
steps.content: Apply baking soda and let it soak up the oil for 5 to 10 minutes, then brush it off. Use an old soft toothbrush to gently scrub the baking soda into the stain. If the baking soda clumps and turns brown, scrape it off and apply a new layer. Repeat until the baking soda no longer changes color, then brush off any leftover soda with the toothbrush. [3] X Research source For delicate or dry-clean-only fabrics (like silk or chiffon): Use cornstarch, talcum powder , or baby powder instead of baking soda and skip the next step. After brushing off the baking soda, you can spray or pour white distilled vinegar directly on the stain to cut through the grease and let it sit for 30 to 60 minutes. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Saturate the area with an enzyme-based laundry detergent or dish soap.
steps.content: Saturate the area with an enzyme-based laundry detergent or dish soap. If you’re using dish soap, make sure it specifically removes grease. Apply enough of your preferred liquid soap to saturate the stain and use a cloth or your finger to rub it in gently. Let the soap sit for 5 minutes. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash as directed and allow the shirt to air dry.
steps.content: Wash as directed and allow the shirt to air dry. Check your clothing’s care label for specific requirements. Try to avoid putting your garment in the dryer—high heat can react with the leftover oil and cause a fire hazard or set the stain into the fabric. [6] X Research source Check your clothing’s care label for washing instructions. Add ½ to 1 cup (118 to 237 mL) of white vinegar to the wash cycle to make the detergent more effective. If the stain is there after washing and air-drying the garment, repeat these steps until it’s gone. If the stain remains, try the next method. For dry clean only items or fabrics like wool, silk, or cashmere: Bring your garment to a professional for special care.

steps.title: Put a piece of cardboard inside the garment behind the stain.
steps.content: Put a piece of cardboard inside the garment behind the stain. Try to cut the cardboard several times larger than the stain, in case the stain spreads. The cardboard will prevent the stain from sinking into the back of your garment. [7] X Research source Try these steps if you’ve washed and dried your oil-stained garment or if the oil stain has been sitting in the item for a long time.

steps.title: Spray the stain with WD-40 and let it sit for 15 to 30 minutes.
steps.content: Spray the stain with WD-40 and let it sit for 15 to 30 minutes. If you have a small stain, spray the WD-40 into a small bowl, and apply it to the stain using a cotton swab. The WD-40 will help break the oil stain down and make it easier to get out. [8] X Research source Alternatively, apply a lemon juice and salt paste to the stain and let it sit for 30 minutes to an hour. Scrub with an old toothbrush, then rinse the garment and wash it as usual. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Use an old toothbrush to scrub baking soda into the stain.
steps.content: Use an old toothbrush to scrub baking soda into the stain. Pour baking soda over the stain in a thick layer. Work it into the fabric using a toothbrush. As you scrub, the baking soda will clump up as it absorbs the oil. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the baking soda treatment until you have no more clumps.
steps.content: Repeat the baking soda treatment until you have no more clumps. Dust off the old, clumpy baking soda, and sprinkle on some new baking soda. Keep scrubbing, dusting, and adding new baking soda until you get no more clumps. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pour dish soap onto the baking soda.
steps.content: Pour dish soap onto the baking soda. Gently swirl the dish soap to get it into the fabric. Make sure that there is still a slick layer of dish soap. If it has completely soaked into the fabric, add a little bit more. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the item and let it air dry.
steps.content: Wash the item and let it air dry. Hand-wash the garment or put it in the washing machine. Check to make sure the stain is gone after it dries. If the stain is still there, repeat this process until it’s gone. [13] X Research source Make sure the stain is completely gone before putting the item in the dryer. High heat can set the stain into the fabric, making it even more difficult to remove.

steps.title: Use rubbing alcohol and bar soap to dissolve the stain.
steps.content: Use rubbing alcohol and bar soap to dissolve the stain. Soak the edge of a cloth in rubbing alcohol and dab at the oil or grease stain. Let it sit for a few minutes, then rub the area with a bar of soap. Rinse and let the garment air dry to make sure the stain is gone. If the stain is still there, repeat this process. [14] X Research source If you have a hair spray that contains alcohol, you can use that in place of rubbing alcohol. However, most modern hair sprays are alcohol-free. This method and the methods below might not be as effective as using dish soap or WD-40, but you can try them if the stain still doesn’t come out.

steps.title: Apply hydrogen peroxide and baking soda to light-colored fabrics.
steps.content: Apply hydrogen peroxide and baking soda to light-colored fabrics. Soak the stain with dish soap and hydrogen peroxide , then sprinkle a thick layer of baking soda over it. Scrub the entire area with a toothbrush, then let it sit for 30 minutes. Rinse the area and let it air dry. If the stain is gone, put the garment in the washer with hot water. [15] X Research source If the stain is still there after air drying, repeat this step or try a different method. Hydrogen peroxide may bleach dark fabrics. Test it out on an inconspicuous area, such as a hem or cuff, before applying it to the stain

steps.title: Rub aloe vera gel onto the stain and wash it in cold water.
steps.content: Rub aloe vera gel onto the stain and wash it in cold water. Lay the garment flat and dampen the stained area with cold water. Rub 100% aloe vera gel into the stain and let it sit for a couple of minutes. Then, wash it with cold water and let it air dry to make sure the stain is completely gone. [16] X Research source If the garment still has a noticeable grease stain, repeat this process. The amino acids in aloe vera make it an effective tool for breaking up grease.

steps.title: Sprinkle salt on the area and apply a pre-wash stain remover.
steps.content: Sprinkle salt on the area and apply a pre-wash stain remover. The salt works like baking soda and absorbs the grease. Let the salt sit for a few minutes, then apply a store-bought grease stain remover . Launder the item in hot water and let it air dry to make sure the stain is gone. [17] X Research source
